translated: The Collection of Long Discourses 2
The Awakening (2)
Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā uruvelāyaṁ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.🔽Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṁ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṁvedī.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā uruvelāyam viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhi rukkha mūle paṭhama abhisambuddhaḥ  tena khalu pana samayena bhagavā sattāham eka pallaṅkena nisinnaḥ hoti vimutti sukha paṭisavedī
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Uruvelā on the bank of the Nerañjarā River at the root of the Bodhi tree, the tree of awakening, newly awakened.🔽For seven days he sat at the root of the Bodhi tree experiencing the bliss of liberation.

original: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rattiyā majjhimaṁ yāmaṁ paṭiccasamuppādaṁ paṭilomaṁ sādhukaṁ manasākāsi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rattiyāḥ majjhimam yāmam paṭiccasamuppādam paṭilomam sādhukam manasā akāsi
translated: Then, with the passing of seven days, after emerging from that concentration, in the middle station of the night, he gave close attention to dependent origination in forward order:

original: “Iti imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhati, yadidaṁ—
analyzed: iti imasmin asati idam na hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati
translated: “When this doesn’t exist, that doesn’t exist. When this ceases, that ceases. That is:
With the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of choices.
With the cessation of choices comes the cessation of consciousness.
With the cessation of consciousness comes the cessation of name-and-form.

analyzed: nāma rūpa nirodhā saṃ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: With the cessation of name-and-form comes the cessation of the six sense spheres.

analyzed: saṅgāyatana nirodhā phassa nirodho  phassa nirodhā vedanā nirodho
translated: With the cessation of the six sense spheres comes the cessation of contact.🔽With the cessation of contact comes the cessation of feeling.
With the cessation of feeling comes the cessation of craving.
With the cessation of craving comes the cessation of clinging.
With the cessation of clinging comes the cessation of existence.
With the cessation of existence comes the cessation of birth.

analyzed: jāti nirodhā jarā maraṇam soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: With the cessation of birth, old age, death, grief, sorrow, pain, unhappiness, and distress all cease.

analyzed: evam etassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodhaḥ hoti iti
translated: This is the cessation of the whole mass of suffering.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
“When the teachings become clear
to the ardent brahmin who meditates,
then all his doubts disappear,
since he has understood the ending of conditions.”
The second.
